fields.title: Linux
fields.content:
# Linux

## General tips

* When you get a "file system is read only" error on a USB drive (mounted at sdb1) try unmounting and remounting as read/write with the following command: `sudo mount -o remount,rw /dev/sdb1`.
* Linux interprets **#!** (called a shebang), when they are the first two characters in a text file, as indicating that the file is a script and the rest of the line gives the absolute path of the interpreter. E.g. Bash `#!/bin/sh`; Python 3.1 `#!/usr/bin/python3.1`.

## Bash/zsh Command Line

* Make the command-line prompt reflect Version Control using [vcprompt](/vcprompt/).
* Terminal Multiplexer Byobu
([Man Page](http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/natty/en/man1/byobu.1.html);
Add new terminal: `F2`; Scroll through terminals: `F3` and `F4`).
* Change your password: `passwd`
* Repeatedly run command: `watch -d -n 0.5 [command]`
* Count number of files in current directory: `ls -l | wc -l`
* Search for string in files (include sub-directories): `grep -rl "string" *`.
* Delete all empty `.xml` files: `find . -name "*.xml" -size 0 -exec rm {} \;`.
* Recursively remove folders and their contents: `rm -rf`.
* List files with **/** added to directory names and **\*** to executables: `ls -F`.
* Mass rename: `zmv -n (*).txt $1.tmp` (`-n` option shows result but does not make the change)
* Checksum: `md5sum ubuntu-10.04-desktop-i386.iso`.
* Find which executable will be used: `which python`.
* Change to the previous working directory: `cd -`.
* Substitution: `!$` Repeats last argument of previous command; `!!` Repeat previous line command; `^foo^bar^` Repeat the previous shell command but replace string "foo" with "bar".
* `echo $?`: Display exit code.
* `su userid`: Switch User.
* traceroute and ping combined: `mtr google.com`.
* Run graphical application as root: `gksudo nautilus`.
* Create link: `ln [-s] file [link]`.
* Reconnect to network connection by restarting network manager service: `sudo service network-manager restart`.
* Monitor several logs: `tail -f [logfile1] [logfile2]...`.
* `df`: Show disk usage.
* Job Control: `jobs` List background jobs; `bg [jobspec]` Run job in background; `fg [jobspec]` Bring specific or most recent job to foreground; `kill %1` Kill first listed job.

## Ultimate Linux Shutdown Process

If all is stuck, and even Ctrl+Alt+backspace does not work, remember this mnemonic: **R**aising **S**kinny **E**lephants **I**s **U**tterly **B**oring:

* ALT+SysRq+**r** (put keyboard in raw mode)
* ALT+SysRq+**s** (sync the disk)
* ALT+SysRq+**e** (terminate all processes)
* ALT+SysRq+**i** (kill all processes)
* ALT+SysRq+**u** (remount all file systems read only)
* ALT+SysRq+**b** (reboot the system)

(SysRq is the same button as print screen on most keyboards)

Less drastically, you can use ALT+SysRq+**k** to kill all processes on the current virtual console (has the effect of restarting the X server).

SysRq is disabled by default so you will have to edit `/etc/sysctl.conf` and change the `kernel.sysrq` value to `1` (and then reboot) to enable these shortcut keys.

## Ubuntu

### Settings

* Bulk change file associations: `sudo vi /usr/share/applications/defaults.list`
    * `:%s/gedit/geany/g` Change default text editor from gedit to geany.
* Prevent keyobard resetting to US layout after reboot:
    1. In `dconf-editor`, navigate to `desktop > ibus > general`.
    1. Enable `use-system-keyboard-layout`.
* Disable auto-open of Nautilus on drive mount: `gsettings set org.gnome.desktop.media-handling automount-open false`
* Stop Wifi being activated after boot ([from](http://www.hecticgeek.com/2012/10/ubuntu-automatically-turns-on-bluetooth-fix/)):
    1. `sudo vi /etc/rc.local`
    1. Add line: `rfkill block wifi`
    1. Also, to keep Bluetooth deactivated): `rfkill block bluetooth`
* Enable `Ctrl+Alt+Backspace` to restart the X server, to recover after the Desktop Environment freezes:
    1. `sudo dpkg-reconfigure keyboard-configuration`
    1. Accept first 5 keyboard options.
    1. Choose `Yes` to use `Control+Alt+Backspace` to terminate the X server.

### OpenDNS

Add OpenDNS servers by editing `/etc/dhcp3/dhclient.conf` and appending the following line to the document:

    prepend domain-name-servers 208.67.222.222,208.67.220.220;

### Logout Keyboard Shortcut

To re-enable Control+Alt+Backspace shortcut to kill the X server:

1. Open Keyboard preferences.
1. Choose Layouts Tab.
1. Press Options Button.
1. Find "Key sequence to kill the x server' option on list.
1. Tick to enable.

### Monitor Network Usage

1. Install vnstat: `sudo apt-get install vnstat`.
1. Create database: `sudo vnstat -u -i eth0`.
1. Show monthly usage: `vnstat -m`.

## Lost Password

Steps to recover lost password in Ubuntu:

1. Choose your Recovery Mode from Grub menu.
2. On the Recovery Menu choose "Drop to root shell prompt".
3. At the command prompt enter `ls /home` to list Userids. (optional)
4. Enter `passwd <userid>` to change the password of that Userid.
5. Enter `exit`.
6. On the Recovery Menu choose "Resume Normal Boot".

fields.title: Rooska
fields.content:
# Rooska

Rooska is the name of the place, next to Bantry Bay, where I bought 30 acres of mountainside.
My plan is to build a place in the country for holidays and retirement.

So far I have built a barn and planted 15 acres with trees.

[![Map of Southwest Ireland](/media/img/thumb/RooskaMap0.jpg "Map of Southwest Ireland")](/media/img/RooskaMap0.jpg)
[![Map of Rooska](/media/img/thumb/RooskaMap1.jpg "Map of Rooska")](/media/img/RooskaMap1.jpg)
[![Aerial Photo of Rooska](/media/img/thumb/RooskaSat.jpg "Aerial Photo of Rooska")](/media/img/RooskaSat.jpg)
[![Map showing boundaries and subdivisions](/media/img/thumb/RooskaMap2.jpg "Map showing boundaries and subdivisions")](/media/img/RooskaMap2.jpg)

To visit Rooska:

1. Take the from Cork N71 West to Bantry.
2. Just before Bantry take the turn off for Kilkrohane.
3. Go down this road for 4 miles until you see a church on the right.
4. At the next left stop and walk up to the property at the end of this road.

[![N71 turn off to Kilkrohane](/media/img/thumb/Directions1.jpg "N71 turn off to Kilkrohane")](/media/img/Directions1.jpg)
[![Rooska Church](/media/img/thumb/Directions2.jpg "Rooska Church")](/media/img/Directions2.jpg)
[![Turnoff to Rooska](/media/img/thumb/Directions3.jpg "Turnoff to Rooska")](/media/img/Directions3.jpg)

fields.title: Profile
fields.content:
## Paul Ahern
![Paul Ahern at Gougane Barra](/media/img/ahernp200x200.png "Paul Ahern at Gougane Barra")
I was born and educated in Ireland and then came to work in London. From 1990 to 2006, I worked in the IT department of Natwest Bank, mainly as a COBOL programmer. I returned to Cork in 2006. In 2006 and 2007, while looking for a mountain by the sea to build my retirement home on, I completed a master's course in Artificial Intelligence at University College Cork. In 2008 I purchased the site for my place in the country at [Rooska](/pages/rooska/ "Rooska"). From 2008 to 2010, I worked in Web Support for Premiere Global Services. Since 2010 I have been working in London as a Web Developer. Currently I am working at [Affectv](https://affectv.com).

fields.title: Libre Office
fields.content:
# Libre Office

Libre Office is a cross-platform office suite available from [libreoffice.org](http://libreoffice.org).

## Calc

* `Ctrl+D`: Copy contents and formatting from topmost cells to rest of selected range in Calc.
* Filter Items in a List:

    1. Populate column `F` with `0` or `1` depending on if the value in on that row of column `C` is listed in column `H`.
    2. Define column `H` as a range called List (Data > Define Range).
    3. Place the following in `F2` and use it to populate the rest of column `F`: `=COUNTIF(List,C2)`
    4. Sort using column `F` to group all of the matching data together.

### Formulae

* Column C or D is blank: `OR(ISBLANK(Sheet1.$C2),ISBLANK(Sheet1.$D2))`
* Column C is not blank and column D is not blank: `AND(NOT(ISBLANK(Sheet1.$C2)),NOT(ISBLANK(Sheet1.$D2)))`

fields.title: UK Postcodes
fields.content:
# UK Postcodes

What they are and how to find them.

## Postcode Structure

UK postcodes are alphanumeric and between five and eight characters long 
(including a single space separating the outward and inward parts of the code), 
e.g. the code for the House of Commons is SW1A 0AA.

The 'Outward' part of the postcode denotes the postal district - for example RH 
for the Redhill area, and then the following number distinguishes the post town - 
broadly speaking the Delivery Office which services the local area. So RH1 is 
Redhill itself, RH10 is Crawley. With larger towns there may be more than 1 number 
in the outward section - Crawley includes RH10 and RH11. The 'Inward' part denotes 
particular parts of the town / Delivery Office area, with the first part - the number - 
being a sector, and the final two letters denoting a group of houses within that area.

For more see [Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_codes_in_the_United_Kingdom).

## To Find a Postcode

1. Go to [postcode.royalmail.com](http://postcode.royalmail.com).
2. Enter the Building Number or Building Name in the fields provided.
3. Enter the Street name.
4. The previous two values are often sufficient but to reduce the 
   number of matches you can enter the Town name as well.
5. Press the "Find Postcode" button.
6. All matching addresses and postcodes are listed. 
   Click on one to see a map showing its location.

## To Find an Address from a Postcode

1. Go to [postcode.royalmail.com](http://postcode.royalmail.com).
2. Click on the "Find an address" tab.
3. Enter the Postcode in the field provided.
4. Press the "Find an Address" button.
5. The address is displayed along with a map showing its location.

fields.title: Firefox
fields.content:
# Firefox

Download from [www.mozilla.org/firefox](http://www.mozilla.org/firefox).

## Add-ons

1. [Adblock Plus](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/adblock-plus/):
Adblocker.
1. [CacheToggle](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/cachetoggle/):
Disable (and optionally clear) the browser cache.
1. [ColorZilla](http://www.colorzilla.com/firefox/):
Advanced Eyedropper, Color Picker, Palette Viewer, etc.
1. [Firesizer](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-us/firefox/addon/firesizer/):
Set window to specific size.
1. [Foxclocks](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/foxclocks/):
Times around the world in Status Bar.
1. [LastPass](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-gb/firefox/addon/lastpass-password-manager/):
Password Manager.
1. [React Developer Tools](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/react-devtools/):
Javascript React tools.
1. [Redux Developer Tools](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/remotedev/):
Javascript Redux tools.
1. [Selenium IDE](http://seleniumhq.org/download/):
Record-and-playback of interactions with the browser.
1. [Stylus](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-GB/firefox/addon/styl-us/):
Apply themes to websites. (try [Solarized Dark Everywhere](https://userstyles.org/styles/98305/solarized-dark-everywhere))
1. [uBlock Origin](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/ublock-origin):
Blocks ads, trackers and malware sites.


## Configuration

* Deactivate New Tab: `about:config` > Find `browser.newtab.url` > Change `about:newtab` to `about:blank` to disable or to a URL to open a specific page.
* Open links in same Tab/Window: `about:config` > `browser.link.open_newwindow` > Change value to 1.
* Enable spell checking: `about:config` > `layout.spellcheckDefault` > Change value to 2

## AwesomeBar/Google Wildcards

Use one of these wildcards (delimited by a space) in the Firefox AwesomeBar to filter the results.

1. **#** Returns results that match the text in the title.
2. **@** Returns results that match the text in the URL.
3. ***** Returns only results that are from the bookmarks.
4. **^** Returns only results that are from the browser's history.
5. **+** Returns only results that have been tagged.

fields.title: CV
fields.content:
# Curriculum Vitae Paul Ahern, Web Developer ## My Story So Far Having worked at Natwest bank in London for 15 years developing Retail Banking applications, using the COBOL programming language, in 2006 I moved back to Ireland to build a place in the country. While there, I attended an MSc course in Artificial Intelligence and worked on a helpdesk supporting web meeting products. Since September 2010, I have been working in London as a Web Developer mostly using Python and Django. As an Irish citizen I am eligible to work in the UK. ## Technical Skills *Programming:* Javascript, Python
*Scripting:* Bash, Python
*Databases:* MySQL, PostgreSQL
*Web:* CSS, Django, HTML, React
*Version Control:* Git
*Management:* Jira, Pivotal Tracker ## Portfolio Examples of my work can be found via links on this page: [ahernp.com/pages/portfolio](/pages/portfolio). ## Education **1987-1990** BA Computer Studies, University College Cork: * Majored in Information Technology; Minored in Geography. **2006-2007** MSc Computer Science, University College Cork: * *Subjects* – Computer Security, Mobile Applications and Artificial Intelligence. * *Projects* – Building a University Timetabling tool using Constraint-Based programming techniques and modelling an adaptive Spam filtering system. ## Experience **2016-** at Affectv in London: > Working as a Web Developer on an in-house web application. > * Maintained a legacy client-side application written using AngularJS. > * Supported the implementation and deployment of targeted advertising campaigns. **2014-2016** at Festicket in London: > Worked as a Web Developer maintaining and enhancing the festicket.com website. > * Integrated Booking Protect (refund protection) into the Festicket purchase process via an API. > * Wrote reporting logic to provide B2B communication to suppliers. Wrote and maintained automated Unit Tests using `py.test`. > * Used a sprint-based Agile approach to deliver changes to festicket.com. > * Provided IT support to staff: Set-up PCs and accounts for new joiners; Offboarded leavers. > * Created and maintained an internal company wiki to document standards and procedures. **2012-2014** at Digitalis Reputations in London: > Worked as a Web Developer migrating an existing in-house tool onto the Django web framework. **2011-2012** at ReportLab in London: > Built several web sites which enable organisations to provide links to PDF output which is dynamically generated from their own data sets using the Reportlab core product. > My team has also built a Django-based wizard which allows users to buy foreign exchange. This has been rolled out across several financial institutions. > Built web sites in direct collaboration with the Clients. Liaised with Clients to manage the interfaces between their systems and Reportlab's. **2010-2011** at Steel Business Briefing in London: > Worked as a Web Developer building sites using the Django web framework. **2008-2010** at Premiere Global Services in Ireland: > Worked as a Web Technical Specialist supporting clients using web-meeting products: Adobe Connect, Microsoft Live Meeting & Webex. **2006-2007** sabbatical in Ireland: > Attended a full-time taught MSc course at UCC titled: Intelligent Systems for Business and Manufacturing. > Learned to drive. **1990-2006** at Natwest Bank in London: > For seven years I worked on a Live Support Team, helping to keep vital bank systems running. This included two years on the Helpdesk dealing with problems reported by non-IT staff across the countrywide branch network. > For several of those years I also worked as a duty-programmer. This involved working at night to see that the batch programs completed successfully and dealing immediately with any problems that arose. > The remainder of my time was spent on application development teams. > As a member of Application Development teams I participated in the end-to-end process of designing, documenting, building and implementing systems. From collecting requirements from users through writing design documents and implementation plans as well as coding and testing my role covered the full development process. > Technical Environment: IBM OS390 mainframe.

fields.title: Twinings Tea
fields.content:
# Twinings Tea

Varieties of tea available from the [Twinings](http://shop.twinings.co.uk/shop/teabag-pick-n-mix.html) website. The number of **!**'s indicates how popular that variety is with people in my office (in 2011).

1. *Everyday Tea*: Blended to be a brighter tasting tea, Everyday tea is perfect all day... everyday. **!!!!**
1. *Traditional English*: A robust blend of the finest Assam, Kenyan and Ceylon teas produces a rich, revitalising cup of tea. **!!!!**
1. *Earl Grey*: Scented with bergamot flavour for a light, soothing drink. **!!!**
1. *Green Pure*: The classic, refreshing taste of pure green tea **!!**
1. *Lemon and Ginger*: A warming infusion, the spiciness of ginger is balanced with clean zesty lemon. **!!**
1. *Assam*: A strong Indian tea with a rich malty character - perfect at any time of the day. **!**
1. *Blended to Recharge*: This refreshing blend combines tangy blackcurrant and hibiscus, with ginseng which is reputed to have reviving properties. **!**
1. *Darjeeling*: A light, distinctive tea from the district renowned for producing the world's most famous tea. **!**
1. *Redbush*: The beating hot sun in Western Africa gives the redbush its juicy, refreshing flavour and copper-red colour. **!**
1. *Amber Keemun Tea*: A bright Keemun black tea with a silky smooth taste.
1. *Blackcurrant, Ginseng & Vanilla*: A luscious infusion with a rich combination of sweet blackcurrant, ginseng root and vanilla.
1. *Blended as a Digestif*: This blend combines fennel seeds with peppermint, both of which have long been used as aids to digestion.
1. *Blended as a Morning Detox*: A purifying blend, combining the fresh taste of verbena, limeflowers and lemon, which has been used for many years, with hot water, as a cleansing drink to start the day.
1. *Blended to Calm*: A soothing blend combining warming rooibos and cocoa beans with lavender and camomile, which has long been used for relaxation.
1. *Blended to Cleanse*: A blend of spearmint, long used to aid digestion; nettle, reputed to have a cleansing effect; and milk thistle, believed to have antioxidant properties.
1. *Blended to Recover*: This cleansing blend combines the fresh taste of peppermint with rooibos and milk thistle, both reputed to have antioxidant properties.
1. *Blossom Earl Grey*: We've created a stylish mix of sweet orange blossom flavour and citrus bergamot.
1. *Blueberry & Apple*: A taste of autumn with a full-bodied blend of sweet red apples and blueberry flavours.
1. *Camomile*: We've picked only the most fragrant flowers to make this light and delicate infusion.
1. *Ceylon*: A bright, medium tea with a slight citrus character. Can be served hot or cooled as a delicious iced tea.
1. *Cranberry & Sanguinello Orange*: The Sanguinello, a Spanish variety of blood orange, perfectly compliments the sharpness of cranberry.
1. *Cranberry, Rasberry & Elderflower*: Lift your senses with a delicious red berry infusion with a hint of elderflower.
1. *Golden Oolong Tea*: A sunny and sweet Oolong Tea with a fragrant taste of spring.
1. *Green Tea with Cranberry*: When summer seems a long way off, our green tea with cranberry could be just the thing to brighten your day.
1. *Green Tea with Orange & Lotus Flower*: This distinctly oriental blend combines zesty orange and a delicate hint of lotus flowers with a lightly aromatic green tea.
1. *Mulled Spice*: Full bodied Assam black tea scented with cinnamon, cloves and Christmas spice flavouring.
1. *Orange, Mango & Cinnamon*: Winter or summer? We love both. That's why we created our orange, mango & cinnamon infusion.
1. *Peppermint Pure*: A refreshing infusion with a clean taste. The cool aroma of mint is both refreshing and soothing.
1. *Pure White*: A delicate, sweet white tea, made from the unopened bud and first leaf of the Camelia Sisensis tea plant.
1. *Rose Garden*: From English country gardens to ancient Turkish palaces, there's nothing like the romance and style of a rose. 
1. *Spring White Tea*: An easy and light white tea, made from Spring picked buds; this is tea at its purest.
1. *Traditional English Decaffeinated*: A robust blend of the finest Assam, Kenyan and Ceylon teas produces a rich, revitalising cup of tea.
1. *White Tea and Pomegranate*: A delicate, light tasting white tea, perfectly balanced with the sweet fruity flavour of pomegranate.

fields.title: HTML Status Codes
fields.content:
# HTML Status Codes

## Informational 1xx

*  100 Continue
*  101 Switching Protocols

## Successful 2xx

*  200 OK
*  201 Created
*  202 Accepted
*  203 Non-Authoritative Information
*  204 No Content
*  205 Reset Content
*  206 Partial Content

## Redirection 3xx

*  300 Multiple Choices
*  301 Moved Permanently
*  302 Found
*  303 See Other
*  304 Not Modified
*  305 Use Proxy
*  306 (Unused)
*  307 Temporary Redirect

## Client Error 4xx

*  400 Bad Request
*  401 Unauthorized
*  402 Payment Required
*  403 Forbidden
*  404 Not Found
*  405 Method Not Allowed
*  406 Not Acceptable
*  407 Proxy Authentication Required
*  408 Request Timeout
*  409 Conflict
*  410 Gone
*  411 Length Required
*  412 Precondition Failed
*  413 Request Entity Too Large
*  414 Request-URI Too Long
*  415 Unsupported Media Type
*  416 Requested Range Not Satisfiable
*  417 Expectation Failed

## Server Error 5xx

*  500 Internal Server Error
*  501 Not Implemented
*  502 Bad Gateway
*  503 Service Unavailable
*  504 Gateway Timeout
*  505 HTTP Version Not Supported

From [www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html](http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html).

fields.title: Google Chrome
fields.content:
# Google Chrome

Download from [www.google.com/chrome](http://www.google.com/chrome).
Alternatively, use [Vivaldi](https://vivaldi.com).

## Extensions

1. [Adblock Plus](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/adblock-plus/cfhdojbkjhnklbpkdaibdccddilifddb/related):
Adblocker.
1. [LastPass](chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/lastpass-free-password-ma/hdokiejnpimakedhajhdlcegeplioahd):
Password Manager.
1. [React](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/react-developer-tools/fmkadmapgofadopljbjfkapdkoienihi):
Javascript React framework Developer Tools.
1. [Redux](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/redux-devtools/lmhkpmbekcpmknklioeibfkpmmfibljd):
Javascript Redux framework Developer Tools.
1. [Stylus](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/stylus/clngdbkpkpeebahjckkjfobafhncgmne):
Apply themes to websites.
1. [Switcheroo](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/switcheroo-redirector/cnmciclhnghalnpfhhleggldniplelbg):
All URL redirections.
1. [uBlock Origin](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/ublock-origin/cjpalhdlnbpafiamejdnhcphjbkeiagm):
Blocks ads, trackers and malware sites.
1. [Visual Event](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/visual-event/pbmmieigblcbldgdokdjpioljjninaim):
Show what event is bound on each DOM element.

Need to select Settings > Extensions > Developer Mode to allow synchronising of Extensions and Themes.

## Search

Default to getting Last Year's results:

1. Open Chrome's Settings Manage Search Engines
1. Add a new search engine under the list of ''Other search engines'' with the following values.
    * Name: *Google (recent)*
    * Keyword: *recent*
    * URL: `http://www.google.com/search?q=%s&tbs=qdr:y&tbo=1`
1. Change this to be your default search
To use `encrypted.google.com` the URL is `https://encrypted.google.com/search?q=%s`.

fields.title: Python
fields.content:
# Python

[TOC]

## Notes

* Sample Script: [sample.py](/media/download/sample.py).
* List attributes of an object: `dir(object)`. 
* Reference object attributes and values via: `object.__dict__`.
* Check if string is numeric: `s.isdigit()`
* String and Integer formatting: `'%s%07d' % ('RPT', 7)` gives `RPT0000007`.
* Identify subclasses: `issubclass(A,B)` returns `True` if A is a subclass of B. (e.g. `issubclass(self.model,Config)`)
* Check for attribute: `hasattr(object,string)` Returns `True` if the string matches an attribute name.
* Use tuple packing and unpacking for atomicity: `x, y = y, x+y`.
* Use generator expressions instead of list comprehensions: `sum(i**2 for i in range(10))`.
* Use decorators to factor-out administrative logic.
* Use `with` to factor out temporary contexts: `with open('data.txt') as f:`
* To use UTF-8 characters in code the module must begin with: `# coding=UTF-8`
* Classes:
    * Define `__repr__` to return representation of instance.
* Function calls: Use keyword arguments and return multiple values as namedtuples.
* Sets: `set_literal = {1,2,3} `
* Strings: Concatenate with `join`.
* Loops: Use `range`, `reversed`, `enumerate` (not for indices), `izip` (to combine iterables), `sorted(iterable[, key=function])`, `for... else:` Else clause executed on completion of `for` (i.e. skipped on `break`).
    * `break` ends the entire loop; `continue` ends the current iteration.
* Operators: Increment `[var] += 1`; Modulo `%`. Ternary operator: `x if a > b else y` Return `x` if `a > b` otherwise return `y`.
    * `map(function, iterable)`: Apply function to each item in iterable and return iterable of results.
    * `reduce(function, iterable)`: Function takes two arguments. Apply function to first two items and then to result and next item. Repeat over iterable. Returns single result.

### Python Debugger

Add the following line to start a debug session at that point in the code at runtime:

    import pdb; pdb.set_trace() # Start debugging

Commands (hit enter to repeat previous command):

* `n` Next
* `p [name]` Print (`pp` Pretty Print)
* `c` Continue
* `r` Continue to next Return
* `s` Step Into
* `l` List
* `b` Breakpoint
* `q` Quit

### Dictionaries

* Loop through keys and values in a dictionary: `for key, value in lookup_address.items()`.
* Retrieve matching value or default: `var = dict.get(key, default_value)`. Ditto and remove matching entry: `var = dict.pop(key, default_value)`.
* Use: `del d[key]` to delete.
* Key filter: `d = {k : d[k] for k in d if not k.startswith('r')} `.
* Construct from iterables: `d = dict(izip(keys, values))`.
* Calculate counters by looping through: `d[key] = d.get(key, 0) + 1`.
* Combine dictionaries: `d = ChainMap(command_line_args, os.environ, defaults)`.

### Exceptions

Access ongoing Exception information: `sys.exc_info()`:

* Capture last line of traceback and line describing problem to include in a message:

        from traceback import format_exc
        . . .
        except Exception as e:
            trace_info = format_exc(sys.exc_info()).split("\n")[-4:-2]

* Print traceback: `print('traceback %s' % (traceback.extract_tb(sys.exc_info()[2])))`.

### Operators

* Increment `[var] += 1`; Modulo `%`.
* Ternary operator: `x if a > b else y` Return `x` is `a > b` otherwise return `y` (equivalent to `a > b ? x : y;` in Java).

### Interaction with Operating System

* Directory containing current module: `cwd = os.path.realpath(os.path.dirname(__file__))`
* Relative Paths: `DATABASE_NAME = os.path.expanduser('~/django-reversion/default.sqlite')` or `DATABASE_NAME = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'default.sqlite')`
* Build path: `PROJECT_PATH = os.path.join(os.path.expanduser('~/code'), 'dmcm/project')`
* Run command: `p = Popen("grep -r --include='*.py' \"%s\" %s" % (string.strip(), PROJECT_PATH), shell=True, stdout=PIPE)`
* Run a script from the Python shell: `execfile("/home/ahernp/test.py")`
* To find where a module was imported from check its `.__file__` attribute.

### Slicing

* `a[start:end]` Items start through end-1.
* `a[start:]` Items start through the rest of the array.
* `a[:end]` Items from the beginning through end-1.
* `a[:]` A copy of the whole array.
* `a[::-1]` Reverse the array.

A step value can be used with any of the above: `a[start:end:step]`. 

The `:end` value represents the first value that is not in the selected slice. The difference between end and start is the number of elements selected (if step is 1, the default). 

Also start or end may be a negative number, which means it counts from the end of the array instead of the beginning.

* `a[-1]` Last item in the array.
* `a[-2:]` Last two items in the array.
* `a[:-2]` Everything except the last two items.

Python is forgiving if there are fewer items than you ask for. For example, if you ask for `a[:-2]` and a only contains one element, you get an empty list instead of an error.

## Recipes

### Write File

    import codecs
    def write_file(filename, data):
        output_filepath = os.path.join(settings.PROJECT_DIR, filename)
        output_file = codecs.open(output_filepath, 'w', 'utf-8')
        output_file.write(data)
        output_file.close()
        print('Data written to %s' % (output_filepath))

Add to existing file: `open(output_filepath, 'a', 'utf-8')`

### Remove Substring

1. Find start of substring: `start_pos = big_string.index('/home/')`
1. Find end of substring: `end_pos = big_string.index("'",start_pos)`
1. Remove substring: `big_string = big_string[:start_pos] + big_string[end_pos:]`

To check if substring is present use: `start_pos = big_string.find('/home/')`

### FTP

    import ftplib
    . . .
    def ftp_to(filename, pdf_stringio):
        ftp_serv = ftplib.FTP(settings.FTP_HOSTNAME, 
                              settings.FTP_USERNAME, 
                              settings.FTP_PASSWORD)
        pdf_stringio.seek(0) # Put file position at beginning of StringIO
        resp = ftp_serv.storbinary('STOR ' + filename, pdf_stringio)
        ftp_serv.close

### Display Progress Percentage

Calculate and display percentage progress:

    rows = source_class.objects.using('legacy').all()
    total = len(rows)
    . . .
    for i, row in enumerate(rows):
       . . .
       percent = float(i) / total * 100
       sys.stdout.write("\r%2.3f%%" % percent)
       sys.stdout.flush()

Example shows percentage to three decimal places, to show percentage as integer use `"\r%2d%%"`.

### Convert to HTML Entities

From Unicode: `u'Østlandet'.encode('ascii', 'xmlcharrefreplace')` gives `'Østlandet'`.

From String: `'Østlandet'.decode('utf-8').encode('ascii', 'xmlcharrefreplace')` also gives `'Østlandet'`.

fields.title: Sprouting
fields.content:
It is all go down by Bantry Bay.

Lots of things are sprouting up on the mountain:

[![Trees starting to sprout at Rooska](/media/img/thumb/sprouting.jpg "Trees starting to sprout at Rooska")](/media/img/sprouting.jpg)

I have also planted some fruit trees (apple, pear, plum and cherry) below the mountain.

The foundation of my Barn has been poured:

[![Foundation of Barn](/media/img/thumb/barnBase.jpg "Foundation of Barn")](/media/img/barnBase.jpg)

I have also commissioned some furniture for the new Barn/Office.

fields.title: New Arrival
fields.content:
Donkey Junior has arrived (in the field next to my new barn):

[![Donkey Junior has arrived](/media/img/thumb/donkey_junior.jpg "Donkey Junior has arrived")](/media/img/donkey_junior.jpg)

Junior is only two days old.

Construction of the barn will give him something to watch:

[![Barn Under Construction](/media/img/thumb/barn2.jpg "Barn Under Construction")](/media/img/barn2.jpg "Barn Under Construction: Note new growth on mountain behind")

No activity today but I am assured that it will be finished within 3--4 weeks.

fields.title: New Barn
fields.content:
Construction of my new barn has begun. Donkey is supervising from the next field:

[![Barn construction begins at Rooska](/media/img/thumb/barn1.jpg "Barn construction begins at Rooska")](/media/img/barn1.jpg)

The view from the window of what shall be my office is as expected. Tomorrow I shall visit a supplier to see about getting some heavy duty mats to protect the (wooden) floor in the main storage area.

[![Floorplan of Barn/Office](/media/img/thumb/barnOffice.jpg "Floorplan of Barn/Office")](/media/img/barnOffice.jpg)

"I love it when a plan comes together."

fields.title: Managing Web Pages
fields.content:
Most web Content Management Systems ([CMS](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_content_management_systems)) build web pages each time they are requested. This blog, for example, is managed by [Wordpress](http://wordpress.org/) in that manner.

Since most page content is not so dynamic as to change between visits this seems inefficient. Sites written in static HTML (e.g. [Hyde](http://ringce.com/hyde)) generally use much less server resource.

I have written a [Django](http://www.djangoproject.com/)-based Content Manager for this site which writes out the HTML when I have finished editing a web page.

The main body of each page is stored in a database as [Markdown](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/) text for easy editing.

At present, are only two data structures in the Content Manager:

1. Pages -- Which merely consist of free-format Markdown and HTML.
1. Lists -- Which are generated using a list item template and set of data lines (see
[Cardgen](/cardgen/) for an example) and then used as the main part of a page.

Each page on this site, apart from in this blog, now has a footer which shows when the content was last changed and a link to the Markdown source.

This is just a proof-of-concept for now. Still to come:

* Blog application.
* Data structure similar to above Lists but which generate multiple similar web pages.

If this works out then I shall make the source code available.

fields.title: Glassy Bay
fields.content:
Bantry Bay looked like glass today, it was so calm:

[![Bantry Bay][TN]][BG]

A second bridge has been built at my place. The old one was crumbling away from the occasional heavy vehicle which passed over it. Now I wait for the concrete to set properly before the people come to build the barn/office.

I have also ordered furniture which will take 6-8 weeks to be made. Looks like it will be near to the end of July before I return to London.

[TN]: /media/img/thumb/bbay.jpg
[BG]: /media/img/bbay.jpg "Glassy Bantry Bay"

fields.title: Green Shoots of Recovery
fields.content:
The quarrying at Rooska has been completed and my neighbour's field tidied up:

[![Quarrying Completed at Rooska](/media/img/thumb/rooskaQuarryingDone.jpg "Quarrying Completed at Rooska")](/media/img/rooskaQuarryingDone.jpg)

In unrelated news, I have seen the first sign of new growth on the mountainside:

[![First green shoots in forest](/media/img/thumb//rooskaFirstGrowth.jpg "First green shoots in forest")](/media/img/rooskaFirstGrowth.jpg)

Planting up the mountain has been completed. Now I need to plant hedges around the boundaries of my lower fields.

fields.title: More Planting
fields.content:
The weather in Ireland has been very fine of late.

This week I have mostly been planting Elm, Japanese Cedar, Scots and Lodgepole Pine, Whitethorn and Larch.

Some photos are available [here](/planting/). My forester reckons that the planting should be completed this week.

Meanwhile, the new bridge has been in use:

[![New Bridge](/media/img/thumb/newBridge.jpg "New Bridge")](/media/img/newBridge.jpg)

& I have marvelled at the arrival of a Tanker:

[![Oil Tanker in Bantry Bay](/media/img/thumb/tanker.jpg "Oil Tanker in Bantry Bay")](/media/img/tanker.jpg)

We make our own entertainment in West Cork you see.

fields.title: Planting Has Begun
fields.content:
The forestry people arrived today and have started planting at my place in the country. Here are some Willow cuttings up on the mountain: [![Willow Cuttings](/media/img/thumb/WillowCuttings.jpg "Willow Cuttings")](/media/img/WillowCuttings.jpg) And a baby Giant Redwood at the bottom of the hill: [![Small Giant Redwood](/media/img/thumb/BabyGiantRedwood.jpg "Small Giant Redwood")](/media/img/BabyGiantRedwood.jpg)

They reckon that it will take only 5 days to plant all 13,310 items. A full list of species and numbers of plants is available here.

fields.title: New Look Site
fields.content: I have applied and new look to my website ahernp.com. It is meant to be reminiscent of the old green-screen terminals. It should be easier on the eyes than the normal white background as well as making highlighted text more prominent. My Wordpress Classic theme has been nerfed to make the blog look like the rest of my site. Apart from the blog the site is made up of static html pages which I wrote a Python 3 script to maintain for me. The script, webgen, is very simple but potentially useful if you need to create a lot of similar pages. I have made it available here if anyone wants to use it. Documentation can be found here.

fields.title: New Roadbed
fields.content:
The landscaping work continues, when the weather permits, at Rooska.

A stone roadbed has been laid across the field to the mountainside:
[![New Roadbed](/media/img/thumb/rooskaRoadbed.jpg "New Roadbed")](/media/img/rooskaRoadbed.jpg)

More rock is being moved to build up the boggy corner of the field:
[![Truck in action](/media/img/thumb/rooskaTruck.jpg "Truck in action")](/media/img/rooskaTruck.jpg)

A minor setback is that the existing bridge, on the way into the site, is crumbling and will need to be replaced. I shall talk it over with my neighbours but will probably get the same guys back who built my new bridge.

fields.title: Landscaping
fields.content: Here is a photo taken from my mountainside today: [![New Road Dug Out](/media/img/thumb/rooskaNewRoad.jpg "New Road Dug Out")](/media/img/rooskaNewRoad.jpg) To the right you can see where the new roadway has been dug across the field. Tomorrow we should start moving stone to build up the roadway. In the middle is our temporary quarry and source of stone. To the left is the digger. After a valiant struggle I wrested some now-redundant fencing from the brambles: [![Dismantled Fencing](/media/img/thumb/rooskaExFence.jpg "Dismantled Fencing")](/media/img/rooskaExFence.jpg) So far my first Premiere-free week is going well. My leaving present was a Leatherman multi-tool which contains a wire-cutter. This has proved most useful, although I had invested in a bolt-cutter for the bigger wires.

fields.title: New Routine
fields.content:
Now that my time is my own again I have had to work out a new daily routine:

* 0700-0730 Breakfast
* 0730-1130 Work with Computer
* 1130-1230 Lunch
* 1230-1330 Travel to Rooska
* 1330-1800 Work on Building and Planting
* 1800-1900 Travel to Clonakilty

While I do not expect to stick rigidly to this schedule it gives me something to aim for. 4 hours computer work and 4+ hours at my place in the country.

The computer work will consist of learning a new language, [Python](http://docs.python.org/py3k/index.html), and building applications to get some programming practice. I have in mind a program which reads a set of template and data file pairs and writes out an entire website.

Planting trees at Rooska should start next week. This week, we are quarrying stone from my neighbour's field to provide material for roadways. My role combines supervision with unskilled labour. Presently I am tidying up, mostly taking down internal fences.

Sadly, the grassy knoll:

[![Before](/media/img/thumb/Connection3.jpg "Before")](/media/img/Connection3.jpg)

Is no more:

[![During](/media/img/thumb/rooskaQuarry.jpg "During")](/media/img/rooskaQuarry.jpg)

fields.title: Premiere Fin
fields.content:
Yesterday, was my last working for [PGi](http://www.pgi.com "Premiere Global Services") in Clonakilty. They and their clients will just have to struggle on without me.

From next week, I shall be taking a more active role in the planting and construction work at [Rooska](/rooska/). This will involve wielding a spade.

I have set a date of the end of June for my return to London.

Today, I rested and then went for a walk at [Rathbarry](http://clonakilty.ie/rathbarry.html).

[![Car](/media/img/thumb/rathbarry.jpg "Car parked near long strand, Rathbarry")](/media/img/rathbarry.jpg)

fields.title: Bridged and Resigned
fields.content:
My new bridge at Rooska has been completed. Now we need to let it settle for a few weeks before running heavy machinery over it.

Soon work can begin dismantling the grassy knoll:

[![Grassy Knoll garnished with Sheep](/media/img/thumb/Connection3.jpg)](/media/img/Connection3.jpg "Grassy Knoll garnished with Sheep")

I have handed in my notice at 
[Premiere](http://www.pgi.com"Premiere Global Services").

My plan is to spend a few months planting trees and then go to London to look for a programming job.

fields.title: New Camera and Bridge
fields.content:
Five years ago I got a Cannon Powershot A410 digital camera. I have been very pleased with its performance. I would have carried on using it if not for a slip on my mountainside which caused me to land on top of it in the mud. It was still usable but only just. Therefore I have recently upgraded to a new Cannon Powershot A495. It is considerably smaller than its predecessor and does not have a viewfinder. I am not convinced that using the screen of a camera to compose a shot is entirely viable outdoors on a sunny day. A new bridge is under construction across the drainage ditch between the long wall and the field at the bottom on the mountainside. This is the first image taken with the new camera to be published on my website:

As can be seen, this will be a heavy-duty bridge suitable for the passage of heavy machinery. The heavy machinery will be along next month to build the road to the mountain.

fields.title: Donkey Family
fields.content:
Donkey Junior and his mum seem to be thriving:

[![Donkey & Junior](/media/img/thumb/donkeys.jpg 
"Donkey & Junior")](/media/img/donkeys.jpg 
"Donkey & Junior: Now pay attention 007")

I visited their field in as non-threatening a manner as possible with a couple of carrots.

Donkey had them both. I don't think that Junior is on solid food yet. He is less 
than two weeks old.

Meanwhile on my side of the fence, the roof is on the barn:

[![Barn Under Construction](/media/img/thumb/barn4.jpg 
"Barn Under Construction")](/media/img/barn4.jpg 
"Barn Under Construction: Roof on")

Up on the mountain most of the trees seem to be a growing:

[![Trees on the mountainside](/media/img/thumb/tree_growth.jpg 
"Trees on the Mountainside")](/media/img/tree_growth.jpg 
"Trees: Most of them seem to be growing")

I saw a Sailboat out on the bay:

[![Sailboat in Bantry Bay](/media/img/thumb/sailboat.jpg 
"Spot the Sailboat in Bantry Bay")](/media/img/sailboat.jpg 
"Bantry Bay: Spot the Sailboat")

fields.title: DMCM version 0.2
fields.content:
I have upgraded this site use version 0.2 of my DMCM (Django Markdown Content Manager) back end.

In addition to making the interface more consistent the changes include:

* Adding a blogging process.
* Added edit links on published pages and a link to edit the entire site on the navigation menu.
* Added [django-revision](http://code.google.com/p/django-reversion/) 
  package to keep history of site contents.
* Upgraded from Django 1.1.1 to 1.2.1.

The next version will include more content types. At present, all of the pages on the site, 
including the blog entries, use the same Django template.

This gives consistency but I wound up putting blog-specific processing in the Python code
which would be more easily maintained in a separate template.

fields.title: Finished Barn
fields.content:
The barn has been built:

[![Finished Barn](/media/img/thumb/barnFin.jpg 
"The Barn is Finished")](/media/img/barnFin.jpg 
"Barn: Construction Complete")

I await the furniture for my office in the back.

The date of July 20, 2010 has been pencilled in for my return to London. By then the remaining walls, fences and gates should be done.

In unrelated news, Cat is continuing his programme of quality assurance in the shop:

[![Cat in the Window](/media/img/thumb/catInWindow.jpg 
"Cat in the Window")](/media/img/catInWindow.jpg 
"Cat in the Window: How much?")

fields.title: Return to London
fields.content:
My place in the country has been completed. Well, phase one anyway.

Newly planted trees are sprouting; Barn/Office has been finished; Roads, Walls and Bridges are done.

Now I can return to London to look for work. In twenty years time I may be able to afford to begin phase two.

On Tuesday 20 July 2010, I shall fly from Cork to London. I am booked into a hotel for the rest of the week but my first objective will be to find a place to rent.

A search on the internet reveals that there are flats available on the street where i lived from 1992-2006. Worth a look at least.

fields.title: Bankers
fields.content:
On Tuesday, July 20, I arrived back in London. I am staying at the [Beaver Hotel](http://www.beaverhotel.co.uk) which is a nice traditional English hotel.

I have a found a flat to rent. Incredibly, it is the same place where I was owner-occupier from 1992-2006.

Unfortunately, the lettings agent needs six months rent in advance - as I am currently looking for work. This would not be a problem except that the bank draft with which I opened a UK account will take 5 working days to clear!

But I shall have my revenge by placing my long term savings and getting a credit card from other institutions. Thus leaving this bank with an unprofitable current account to look after.

Meantime, I shall be staying on at the hotel into next week.

When I first moved to London in 1990 I was able to rent and move into a flat within 24 hours of my arrival. The process seems to have become more complex since then.

fields.title: New Old Flat
fields.content:
I am now renting the flat which I used to own. How unlikely is that? Most of my old furniture is still here.

Now to find a job. My ideal would be to join a Web Development team in the City but I would not be too troubled by going back to work in the IBM mainframe environment. That is where I spent most of my career hitherto.

In the last couple of weeks, I have wandered around many of my old haunts and been surprised by how many businesses and office-buildings have closed and shuttered.

Some relatively new buildings seem derelict. This cannot be a good sign.

Finding work in London is still going to be easier than doing so in Ireland.

fields.title: Ici Londres
fields.content:
I have settled back into life here in London.

Given the amount of time on my hands while moving (e.g. waiting for my bank to finish a 5-day
rain-dance around the bank draft I brought from Ireland), 
I have been able to go to some of the sights:

* [British Museum](http://www.britishmuseum.org)
* [St Paul's](http://www.stpauls.co.uk "St Paul's Cathedral")
* [Tate Modern](http://www.tate.org.uk/modern/ "former Bankside power station")
* [Natural History Museum](http://www.nhm.ac.uk "in South Kensington")
* [Science Museum](http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk "in South Kensington")
* [Imperial War Museum](http://london.iwm.org.uk "in Lambeth")

The last contains a German 88mm flak gun from World War 2, 
which from newsreels I though would be bigger. There must have been several models.

fields.title: New Job
fields.content:
On 1 September I shall start working for a company called 
[Steel Business Briefing](http://www.steelbb.com). 
They provide news and pricing information about the steel industry. 
My role will be as a web developer using the Python programming language 
and the Django development framework.
        
This is pretty much my dream job. 
I have been teaching myself Python for the last year or so to prepare for to take up web development.
Their office is on the south side of the City of London 
so I can even recreate my walk to work
(since I am currently renting the flat which I used to own!).

fields.title: New Old Routine
fields.content:
From 1996-2006 I walked to work in London. In tube-station terms I went from [Surrey Quays](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrey_Quays_railway_station) to [Aldgate East](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aldgate_East_tube_station). My new walk to work is from Surrey Quays to [Monument](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank-Monument_station). This was especially convenient yesterday as services on the London Underground were disrupted by strikes.

My new routine contains precisely the same walk to work until I cross Tower Bridge. Before, I went straight on, now I turn left and pass in front of the Tower of London.

For the last week, I have been trying out eateries near to my new place of work. [Grazing](http://www.grazingfood.com) is just down the street and was nice. Today I discovered [The Walrus and The Carpenter](http://www.citypubs.co.uk/pubs/thewalrusandthecarpenter.html) pub which serves food upstairs. I had some Fish and Chips there today.

My new job seems quite interesting, but it is early days yet. I am still finding my way around the [django](http://www.djangoproject.com/) which has already been built.

fields.title: Traffic Jam
fields.content:
While walking home along the bank of the Thames in front of the Tower of London, I realised that my journey was about to be delayed:

[![Tower Bridge Open](/media/img/thumb/rivertraffic.jpg "River and Road Traffic at Tower Bridge")](/media/img/rivertraffic.jpg "Tower Bridge: River Traffic wins over Road Traffic")

Using my new [smartphone](http://www.htc.com/www/product/desire/specification.html), I recorded the incident for posterity.

Meantime at work, I am on the verge of becoming productive, having familiarised myself with the way the company uses [Django](http://www.djangoproject.com/) and related technologies.

Tragically, my first payslip did not include a deduction for income tax. I am assured that it will be put right for next month. For the period between being paid and receiving the payslip I thought myself better off than was in fact the case. Duh.

fields.title: Dental Trauma
fields.content:
On 31 August I went to my dentist to have a crown fitted. I had not been to see a dentist during my 4 years in Ireland and the tooth was too far gone for a lesser treatment. The x-ray showed only 1mm of enamel remained protecting the nerve at one spot.

Unfortunately, when fitting the crown the nerve seems to have been have been exposed and killed. This left me with an infection/toothache which got progressively worse. On my next visit the dentist confirmed that the root was now infected. Since my policy is to go for minimum medical interventions we decided to try a course of antibiotics first. He prescribed amoxicillin.

This suppressed the infection for a few days but the pain returned before I had even completed the course. The day before my next appointment I got a call to say that it was being cancelled and that the practice was closing for 2 weeks.

At this point, I made an executive decision and made an appointment to see another local dentist. Saw him a few days later and told my story. He took an x-ray to make sure nothing weird was going on and suggested that it would be best to allow the original dentist to complete my treatment. He prescribed some much stronger antibiotics (clindamycin) to relieve the pain.

I called my usual dentist and was given an appointment for the following week. The practice had been closed for only 1 week. When I went in I found that my dentist had had his own medical emergency and been taken to hospital to have an operation on his spine.

This time, we agreed that I needed to have an emergency root-canal. I came back 2 days later (on 13 October) and it was done. This was not a painful process but did involve an entire hour in the chair. I started a new course of clindamycin to kill off the infection.

Fortunately, I make a point of using weaker painkillers (paracetamol) so when I took ibuprofen just before the anaesthetic wore off it worked perfectly.

Last week, (on 21 October) I returned to my dentist who checked the tooth and confirmed that the infection had cleared up. I have to return at the end of November for another check.

Overall I am happy with my dentist and will continue to visit him. Although something went wrong with the crown, it is partly my own fault for not having the tooth treated earlier. Also, he did point out the risks beforehand.

The moral of this story is not to carry an infected tooth around with you for a month. It will mess you up!

fields.title: Tea
fields.content:
We ran out of Tea at the office this week. Since we are based in the City of London this is somewhat embarrassing.

I have tea every day, a mug at teatime, but am not a connoisseur. So it was with surprise that I discovered that there are 33 varieties available from the 
[Twinings](http://shop.twinings.co.uk/shop/teabag-pick-n-mix.html) website alone.

We have a 4-compartment Twinings wooden caddy box in the office. I have ordered some replacement tea bags.

In the meantime, I am taking soundings to see which varieties are favoured by my colleagues: [Tea](/twinings-tea/ "Twinings Tea").

fields.title: Barn Menaced by Giant Sheep
fields.content:
Next month I am visiting Rooska. It will allow me to see if my barn has remained watertight over the winter.

In the meantime, a neighbour has sent me some photos of the place under snow.

I especially like the one with the giant sheep:

[![Barn Menaced by Giant Sheep in the Snow](/media/img/thumb/giant_sheep.jpg "Barn Menaced by Giant Sheep in the Snow")](/media/img/giant_sheep.jpg "Barn in the Snow: Menaced by Giant Sheep")

It is all a trick of the light.

fields.title: Rooska Growth
fields.content:
I have just been to Ireland on an inspection tour of my place in the country. The new is good. 

Most of the trees on the mountain survived the winter:

[![Trees protruding from grasses on mountain](/media/img/thumb/trees_2011.jpg "Trees 1 year after planting")](/media/img/trees_2011.jpg "Tree Growth: April 2011")

The fruit trees are also alive:

[![Flowering Pear Tree](/media/img/thumb/pear_tree.jpg "Pear tree 1 year after planting")](/media/img/pear_tree.jpg "Pear Tree: April 2011")

The edges of the digging we did last year have been softened:

[![Stream banks softened by new growth](/media/img/thumb/stream.jpg "Stream banks 1 year after digging")](/media/img/stream.jpg "Growth along Stream: April 2011")

The barn is still standing and remained watertight:

[![Barn as of April 2011](/media/img/thumb/barn_2011.jpg "Barn and new growth in April 2011")](/media/img/barn_2011.jpg "Barn and Environs: April 2011")

fields.title: Demolition
fields.content:
I went for a walk around the city after lunch today and visited my old office. To my surprise, it was in the process of being demolished:

[![Goodmans Fields being Demolished](/media/img/thumb/goodmans_demolition.jpg "My old office at Goodmans Fields being demolished")](/media/img/goodmans_demolition.jpg "Goodmans Fields: Demolition")

Maybe this is an omen. I worked in that building for over 10 years.

fields.title: Tea Time
fields.content:
Back in January we ran out of tea in my office. So I took a vote on people's preferred varieties ([Tea](/twinings-tea/ "Twinings Tea")).

Now I have invested in and filled 
[Teabox](http://shop.twinings.co.uk/shop/teabag-pick-n-mix/12-compartment-wooden-caddy-box-empty.html "12-compartment Teabox"):
from Twinings.

[![Twinings 12-compartment Teabox in Office](/media/img/thumb/teabox.jpg 
"Twinings 12-compartment Teabox in Office")](/media/img/teabox.jpg 
"Teabox: 12 compartments of Tea")

I'm just trying to raise the tone!

In unrelated news I shall be moving to a smaller flat next month. It has been nice being back in my old 2-bedroom flat but a lower rent is more useful than the additional space. I have found a studio-flat about half a mile south of my current residence.

As an added bonus, after I move in, all my stuff will be within easy reach!

fields.title: Delay at Tower Bridge
fields.content:
On my walk to work this morning, Tower Bridge opened before my disbelieving eyes:

[![Tower Bridge Open](/media/img/thumb/TowerBridge.jpg "Tower Bridge Open")](/media/img/TowerBridge.jpg "Tower Bridge: Opened on my walk to work")

Not the sort of delay I had on my commutes in Ireland!

My employer has been taken over by 
[McGraw-Hill](http://www.mcgraw-hill.com/ "McGraw-Hill Companies"). 
They don't use Python or indeed do much in-house development. My team and I appear not to have a long-term future. Time to consider my next move.

fields.title: Taken Over
fields.content:
## SBB Taken Over By McGraw-Hill

The company I've worked for since September 2010, 
[Steel Business Briefing](http://sbb.com/ "Global Steel News"), 
was bought by 
[McGraw-Hill](http://www.mcgraw-hill.com/ "Publishing, Commodity Pricing, Credit Rating...")
in July 2011.

A couple of weeks ago my project was cancelled. So now I am looking for gainful employment.

I've updated my [CV](/cv/) ([pdf](/media/doc/CV2012.pdf)).

Although I've learned a lot about web development in the past year it would probably be best for me in my next role to join an established team, preferably in the City.

fields.title: New Job 2011
fields.content:
Yesterday was my last day of employment at SBB/McGraw-Hill. As HR prefer to put it: My position has been made redundant. The writing has been on the wall since McGraw-Hill bought SBB in the summer and I learned that they, basically, don't write their own software.

The good news is that yesterday I was offered and have accepted a web developer position with a software company called ReportLab based in Wimbledon. Their site is at 
[www.reportlab.com](http://www.reportlab.com).

My commute will be about 1 hour by train. If the new job works out then I shall move to the vicinity of Wimbledon next July (when the lease on my flat expires) and resume walking to work!

Wimbledon is such a nice area that it is more expensive to live there than in my old neighbourhood near the city. I will aim for a 3-mile walk to work which should allow me to live somewhere more reasonable.

fields.title: Site Redesign
fields.content:
I have redesigned my [ahernp.com](http://ahernp.com) site to make it more readable.

In recent years, I have become a fan of readability software. 
This clears the clutter from web pages and leave the main text on a plain background.
There are various bookmarklets, Firefox add-ons and hosted services, for example:

* [iReader](http://code.google.com/p/ireader-extension/) ([and for Firefox](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/ireader/))
* [Readable](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/readable/)
* [Readability](https://www.readability.com/)

Readability functionality is also built in to Apple's Safari browser nowadays.

Anyway, it occurred to me that the sites I admire tend to look as though they had already been run through such software.
Hence my redesign.

There are now no graphics or images on the site at all (apart from a `favicon.ico` and the pictures). It is now all about the text content.

fields.title: MySQL
fields.content:
# MySQL

## SQL

* Show all data in a table: `SELECT * FROM [table];`
* Vertical format results: `SELECT * FROM [table]\G`
* `SELECT [col], count(*) FROM [table] GROUP BY 1 HAVING count(*) > 1;`
* `UPDATE [table] SET [col] = 0 where [col] is null;`
* `INSERT INTO [table] ([column1], [column2]) VALUES ([literal|now()]);`
* `INSERT INTO [table1] ([col1], [col2]) SELECT a.[col1], a.[col2] FROM [table2] a;`
* Redirect output to file: `TEE [file]`. Stop redirect `NOTEE`
* Run SQL file: `SOURCE [file]`

## Meta

* Database sizes: `SELECT table_schema 'Data Base Name', SUM(data_length + index_length) / 1024 / 1024 'Data Base Size in MB' FROM information_schema.TABLES GROUP BY table_schema;`
* Number of rows per table: `SELECT table_name, FORMAT(table_rows,0) FROM information_schema.TABLES WHERE table_schema = '[database_name]';`
* Show structure of tables: `SELECT table_name, ordinal_position, column_name, data_type, character_maximum_length FROM columns where table_schema = '[database]' order by 1,2;`
* Rename table: `ALTER TABLE [table] RENAME [new_table];`
* Rename column: `ALTER TABLE [table] CHANGE COLUMN [col] [new_col] varchar(32);`
* Make an existing column nullable: Columns are nullable by default so just modify the column, leaving the NOT NULL clause off. E.g. `ALTER TABLE [table] MODIFY [boolean_column] BOOL;`
* Show user access: `SHOW GRANTS FOR '[user]'@'localhost';`
* `CREATE USER '[user]'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY '[password]';`
* `GRANT ALL ON [database].* to [user]@localhost;`
* List all users: `SELECT * FROM mysql.user;`
* Refresh cached permissions: `FLUSH PRIVILEGES;`
* List all databases on the sql server: `SHOW DATABASES;`
* Switch to a database: `USE [database];`
* See all the tables in the database: `SHOW TABLES;`
* See database's field formats: `DESCRIBE [table];`
* Delete a database: `DROP DATABASE [database];`
* Delete a table: `DROP TABLE [table];`

## Command Line

* To start server: `sudo /etc/init.d/mysql start`
* To stop server: `sudo /etc/init.d/mysql stop`
* To restart server: `sudo /etc/init.d/mysql restart`
* To check the status of server: `sudo /etc/init.d/mysql status`
* Login: `mysql -uroot -proot`
* Create database: `mysql --user=root --execute="CREATE DATABASE if not exists [database] character set utf8"`

## mysqldump

* Dump single table: `mysqldump -u[user] -p[password] [database] [table] > [file]`
* Data only: `mysqldump --password=[password] --skip-triggers --compact --no-create-info [database] > [file]`
* When dumping a live database use the `--lock-tables=false` option.

## .my.cnf

Create a `.my.cnf` configuration file in your home directory. Containing:

    [client]
    user = <userid>
    password = <password>
    database = <db_name>
    [mysql]
    # Do not apply updates or deletes which lack where clauses
    safe-updates
    # Include database name in prompt
    prompt=\d>\_

fields.title: Rooska 2012
fields.content:
## Rooska in the Spring

Last week I was in Ireland visiting my place in the country. The barn is intact. The flora in and around the new drains are recovering. Most of the trees on the mountain are doing well. I even found time to visit my old boss, Mr Cat.

Here are the photos:

[![Frontgate](/media/img/thumb/rooskaFrontgate.png "Frontgate")](/media/img/rooskaFrontgate.png "Frontgate: April 2012")
[![Barn](/media/img/thumb/rooskaBarn2012.png "Barn")](/media/img/rooskaBarn2012.png "Barn: April 2012")
[![Footbridge](/media/img/thumb/rooskaFootbridge.png "Footbridge")](/media/img/rooskaFootbridge.png "Footbridge: April 2012")
[![Trees on the Mountain](/media/img/thumb/rooskaTrees2012.png "Trees on the Mountain")](/media/img/rooskaTrees2012.png "Trees on the Mountain: April 2012")
